{"rule":"MORFOLOGIK_RULE_EN_US","sentence":"^\\QAny other combination of the two modes is possible and we will have moments where the first mode is dominant and viceversa.\\E$"}
{"rule":"MORFOLOGIK_RULE_EN_US","sentence":"^\\QThe second normal mode corresponds to a motion of the pendulums in counterphase.\\E$"}
{"rule":"THE_ARE","sentence":"^\\QWe can put those numbers into a matrix: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Similarly we can put the values of \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q into a matrix: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Also we have that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q So the Lagrangian for the system is: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The terms of the are: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Evaluating the partial derivatives we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q We simplified the summation in the second line because of the Kronecker delta, and we can notice that in the third line the two terms are actually identical due to the fact that \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and we are summing over all indices.\\E$"}
{"rule":"THE_ARE","sentence":"^\\QThe calculation for the kinetic energy is the same and we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Hence we evaluate the total time derivative: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q So the are: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q for all the possible \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q.\\E$"}
{"rule":"ADJECTIVE_ADVERB","sentence":"^\\QIn fact this condition reduces to the \"usual\" case if \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and the vectors are real valued: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q We also want to normalize the vectors.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE","sentence":"^\\QThe calculation for the kinetic energy is the same and we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Hence we evaluate the total time derivative: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q So the are: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q for all the possible \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE","sentence":"^\\QAlso assume that the kinetic energy taxes the form of: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Expanding the potential in terms of \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q gives: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Qsame term \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The kinetic energy instead becomes: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The Lagrangian then becomes: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Let us divide the Lagrangian by \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and define: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The new Lagrangian becomes: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q From we get two equations: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q coupled equations Now impose that the solutions are in the form: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The system becomes: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q In this case the generalized eigenvalue equation reduces to the usual case and we get the two solutions \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE","sentence":"^\\QAlso in this new basis we have: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q And so the become: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Those are not coupled equations and so they can be solved separately.\\E$"}
{"rule":"THE_ARE","sentence":"^\\QNotice that the coordinates \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q in this case are equivalent to the ones we chose: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q This can be expressed in matrix form: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q If we evaluate all the partial derivatives we get that the matrix \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The Lagrangian finally looks like this: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q And the are: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Dividing by \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q And so we define a new matrix for the potential: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and for the kinetic energy: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q To find the eigenvalues we need to solve: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q From which we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q So we get the values for \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q We want solutions like \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE","sentence":"^\\QIn this case the generalized normalization reduces to the regular one and we have: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The solution can be written has: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The orthonormality of the eigenvectors leads to: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q We call \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q normal modes of the system.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE_2","sentence":"^\\QIf \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Which implies: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Instead if we put \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Which implies: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q This means that the first normal mode corresponds to a motion where the spring is never contracted and the pendulums move identically.\\E$"}

{"rule":"MORFOLOGIK_RULE_EN_US","sentence":"^\\QTo explain the difference between a virtual displacement and an actual displacement we can analyze the displacement of a moving object on an inclined plane with the angle changing over time: [width=0.5,inkscapelatex=false]res/svg/virtualdisplacement Displacement and virtual displacement Where: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is the virtual displacement \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is the actual displacement Now consider a system of particles at equilibrium so that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The total force is composed of two separated parts: Applied forces \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Constraint forces \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q At equilibrium we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Now we consider only system with zero total virtual work and we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The last equation represents the condition of equilibrium for a system such that \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and is called principle of virtual work.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE","sentence":"^\\QTo explain the difference between a virtual displacement and an actual displacement we can analyze the displacement of a moving object on an inclined plane with the angle changing over time: [width=0.5,inkscapelatex=false]res/svg/virtualdisplacement Displacement and virtual displacement Where: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is the virtual displacement \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is the actual displacement Now consider a system of particles at equilibrium so that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The total force is composed of two separated parts: Applied forces \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Constraint forces \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q At equilibrium we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Now we consider only system with zero total virtual work and we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The last equation represents the condition of equilibrium for a system such that \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and is called principle of virtual work.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE","sentence":"^\\Q\\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q These are called the equations of transformation and they have some properties: explicitly contain the constraints can depend on time or not \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q's may not be lengths \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q's may not be grouped in vectors \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q's are scalars An example of the use of generalized coordinates is the use of polar coordinates for the analysis of the pendulum system.\\E$"}

{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE","sentence":"^\\QWe also know that the new Lagrangian and the old Lagrangian must describe the same system and they have this relation: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q So there must exist a function \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q such that this is true for a transformation to be canonical.\\E$"}

{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE_2","sentence":"^\\QSuppose that every force is expressed through a potential: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Since \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q (the total potential) must be a function of only the coordinates \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q we get that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Rewriting we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q If the potential does not depend on the generalized velocities we can subtract its derivative with respect to \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q, which will just be 0: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q We define the Lagrange function or Lagrangian as: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Finally we can write the Euler-Lagrange equations: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Here are some basic properties of : They are \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q order differential equations There is a total of \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q total initial conditions \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q which means we have \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q variables \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q but the Lagrangian is not the mechanical energy, it is just a mathematical tool If \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is a Lagrangian of the system then \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is still Lagrangian If \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is a Lagrangian of the system and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is an arbitrary function of coordinates and time then \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is a Lagrangian If we have two system, let's call them \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q then the Lagrangian of the total system \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q in general is not: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Qinteraction term \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q but if the systems interact weakly then: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q If the potential \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q does not depend on time explicitly then the system is conservative: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Instead if \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q depends on time explicitly we have that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The extra term appearing in \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is not present in the expression for work, meaning that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q so the system is not conservative.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_PARENTHESIS_WHITESPACE","sentence":"^\\QHence, we proved that implies .\\E$"}

{"rule":"IT_SELF","sentence":"^\\QAbsolute, true, and mathematical time, of it self and from its own nature, flows equably without relation to anything external, and by another name is called 'duration'; relative, apparent, and common time is some sensible and external (whether accurate or unequable) measure of duration by means of motion, which is commonly used instead of true time, such as an hour, a day, a month, a year.\\E$"}

{"rule":"RETURN_BACK","sentence":"^\\QThe two scientists created a setup consisting of an interferometre, a device in which a laser beam, generated by a source, splits into two other beams which travel along identical arms and then get reflected back into a screen.\\E$"}
{"rule":"COMMA_COMPOUND_SENTENCE_2","sentence":"^\\QSuppose that every force is expressed through a potential: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Since \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q (the total potential) must be a function of only the coordinates \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q we get that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Rewriting we get: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q If the potential does not depend on the generalized velocities we can subtract its derivative with respect to \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q, which will just be 0: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q We define the Lagrange function or Lagrangian as: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Finally we can write the Euler-Lagrange equations: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Here are some basic properties of : They are \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q order differential equations There is a total of \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q total initial conditions \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q which means we have \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q variables \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q but the Lagrangian is not the mechanical energy, it is just a mathematical tool If \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is a Lagrangian of the system then \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is still Lagrangian If \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is a Lagrangian of the system and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is an arbitrary function of coordinates and time then \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is a Lagrangian If we have two system, let's call them \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q and \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q then the Lagrangian of the total system \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q in general is not: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Qinteraction term \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q but if the systems interact weakly then: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q If the potential \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q does not depend on time explicitly then the system is conservative: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q Instead if \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q depends on time explicitly we have that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q The extra term appearing in \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q is not present in the expression for work, meaning that: \\E(?:Dummy|Ina|Jimmy-|Dummy-|Maniquí-|Maniquíes-)[0-9]+\\Q so the system is not conservative.\\E$"}
